subject: Re: JUnit vs. Agitator
msgSnippet: ... system ... In this case points was the count of JUnit or Agitator assertions -- negative values were non-sensical. And I m not sure checking the
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Now I don't necessarily agree that checking an exception message is
> /good design/. I also don't necessarily agree that having a negative
> value for 'score' is cause for an exception--it depends where the
system
> boundaries are.

In this case "points" was the count of JUnit or Agitator assertions --
negative values were non-sensical.

And I'm not sure checking the exception message in my test is a
question of design at all, but out of curiousity, how do you TDD
throwing an exception?

> Finally, I should mention that this is not the kind of design problem I
> have in mind when I made my admittedly baseless claim. Since it was
> baseless, I should revise my claim. Here it is:
>
> When I write JUnit tests, I am forced to deal with dependency
> problems in my code. I don't yet have any evidence that Agitator
> would help me with that. I am concerned that since Agitator helps
> me /not/ write JUnit tests, it might also help me /not/ feel the
> pain of those kinds of dependency problems.
>

I think it is a reasonable concern but not something to fear in
practice. I don't think I've ever worked with a customer where I
haven't pointed to the screen and said something about dependency
injection.

fwiw about the only JUnit tests that I haven't written becuase of
Agitator are the ones I would have written to fix the bugs that would
have otherwise have been reported. :)

Jtf
